TI: Role of CA1 GABAA and GABAB receptors on learning deficit induced by D-AP5 in passive avoidance step-through task.
AB: To investigate the interaction between hippocampal gamma-aminobutyric acid GABAA receptor (GABAAR) or GABAB receptor (GABABR) and N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) in the acquisition of passive avoidance memory in rats, we used GABAA or GABAB agents, D-AP5 (as a NMDAR antagonist), and a combination of the mentioned drugs in a step-through task. All agents were microinjected into the intra-CA1 regions at a volume of 1microl/rat, prior to training. GABAAR agonist muscimol (0.2microg/rat), selective GABABR agonist baclofen (0.5microg/rat) or NMDAR antagonist D-AP5 (0.25microg/rat) decreased step-through latency, indicating a memory retention impairment. Neither GABAAR antagonist bicuculline (0.0625-0.25microg/rat) nor GABABR antagonist phaclofen (0.1-0.5microg/rat) altered memory retrieval by itself. Moreover, the lower dose of muscimol (0.05microg/rat) decreased D-AP5 (0.125microg/rat) response on memory acquisition, but bicuculline did not alter the D-AP5 response. Furthermore, baclofen and phaclofen at the dose of 0.1microg/rat potentiated D-AP5 response at the doses of 0.0625 and 0.125microg/rat, but abolished memory impairment induced by D-AP5 at the higher dose (0.25microg/rat). The results suggest that the microinjection of GABAA and GABAB agents into the CA1 region differently affects memory acquisition deficit induced by D-AP5. The activation of GABAARs increased the impairment effect of D-AP5 on passive avoidance memory, but their blockade did not have an effect. Also, the activation or blockade of GABABRs induced a similar and dual effect.
